document.docAuthor: Estol, Narelle, Marta, Kimberly S. & Rodrigues, Everton Nei Lopes
document.docTitle: Tullgrenella brescoviti Estol & Marta & Rodrigues 2020, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: On the Neotropical spider genus Tullgrenella Mello-Leitão, 1941: two new species complementary descriptions and new records (Araneae: Salticidae)

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type material .
Holotype :
male, La Paz (Laguna Viscachani, 16º31’S , 68º12’W ,
3600 m asl
, collected in Puna), Bolivia ,
05.VIII.1993
, A.D. Brescovit leg. (
MCN 23871
)
.
Paratype :
female, La Paz ( Valle del Zongo , 16º31’S , 68º12’W ,
3600 m asl
), Bolivia ,
05.VIII.1993
, H. Höfer leg. (
MCN 24104
)
.
Etymology. The specific name honors the arachnologist Antonio Domingos Brescovit (IBSP), collector of the type specimen.

Diagnosis. Males of
T. brescoviti
sp. nov.
species resemble those of
T. guayapae Galiano, 1970
(see Galiano 1970 , figs 10–13) and
T. morenensis (Tullgren, 1905)
(see Galiano 1970 , figs 1–2) by the shape of embolus base, oval and developed, and cymbium pointed, sickle-shaped ( Figs 7, 10 , 23, 25 ), but differ from
T. guayapae
by the larger TmA, by the shape of RTA, less excavated ( Figs 8 , 25 ) and distal embolus not exceeding the length of the cymbium apex ( Figs 7, 9 , 23 ), and differ from
T. morenensis
by the shape of tegulum more oblique, TDD wider than in
T. morenensis
( Fig. 7 ) and the shape of the RTA, more acute in
T. brescoviti
( Fig. 8 ). Females of
T. brescoviti
sp. nov.
resemble those of
T. didelphis (Simon, 1886)
(see Galiano 1963 , fig. 11 and Galiano 1970 , fig. 58) and those of
T. morenensis
(see Galiano 1970 , fig. 57) by the shape of copulatory ducts, long with the first loop oval and by the presence of posteriorly-opening coupling pocket, but differ from both species by the smaller spermathecae, distant from each other ( Figs 11, 12 , 28, 29 ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 1–6.
Tullgrenella nadjae
sp. nov.
: 1–4, left male palp: 1, ventral view; 2, retrolateral view; 3, prolateral view; 4, dorsal view. 5–6, epigyne: 5, ventral view; 6, dorsal view, cleared. Scale bars: 0.25 mm. Abbreviations: C, conductor; CD, copulatory ducts; CO, copulatory openings; Cy, cymbium; E, embolus; EB, embolus base; FD, fertilization ducts; pCP, posteriorly-opening coupling pocket; RTA, retrolateral tibial apophysis; S, spermatheca; T, tegulum; TDD, tegulum distal division; Ti, tibia; TmA, terminal apophysis.

FIGURES 7–12.
Tullgrenella brescoviti
sp. nov.
: 7–10, left male palp: 7, ventral view; 8, retrolateral view; 9, prolateral view; 10, dorsal view. 11–12, epigyne: 11, ventral view; 12, dorsal view, cleared. Scale bars: 0.25 mm. Abbreviations: C, conductor; CD, copulatory ducts; CO, copulatory openings; Cy, cymbium; E, embolus; EB, embolus base; FD, fertilization ducts; pCP, posteriorly-opening coupling pocket; RTA, retrolateral tibial apophysis; S, spermatheca; T, tegulum; TDD, tegulum distal division; Ti, tibia; TmA, terminal apophysis.

FIGURES 13–14.
Tullgrenella guayapae Galiano, 1970
, epigyne: 13, ventral view; 14, dorsal view, cleared. Scale bars: 0.25 mm. Abbreviations: CD, copulatory ducts; CO, copulatory openings; FD, fertilization ducts; pCP, posteriorly-opening coupling pocket; S, spermatheca.

FIGURES 15–19. Body, dorsal view: 15–16,
Tullgrenella nadjae
sp. nov.
: 15, male; 16, female; 17–18,
Tullgrenella brescoviti
sp. nov.
: 17, male; 18, female; 19,
Tullgrenella guayapae Galiano, 1970
: female. Scale bars: 1 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Distribution. Known only from the type locality in Bolivia ( Fig. 32 ).

Natural history. The species was collected in Puna grassland ecoregion, above 3600 m . Puna is characterized by the montane grasslands and shrublands biome, is found in the central Andes Mountains of South America.
